title: Sweeteners in diet drinks may steal years from the brain
summary:
Summary: A new study suggests that consuming artificial sweeteners found in diet drinks may be linked to accelerated brain aging.  The research indicates a correlation between sweetener intake and reduced cognitive function, particularly in areas related to memory and processing speed. 
Implications:  This is informational only.

title: Scientists watch Parkinson’s protein drill holes in brain cells
summary:
Summary: Scientists have discovered that a protein associated with Parkinson's disease, called alpha-synuclein, can create holes in brain cells, potentially contributing to the disease's progression. This finding sheds light on the cellular mechanisms behind Parkinson's and could lead to new therapeutic targets.

Implications: This is informational only.

title: Scientists reveal how breakfast timing may predict how long you live
summary:
Summary: A new study suggests that the timing of your breakfast may be linked to your lifespan.  Researchers found that people who ate breakfast earlier in the day tended to live longer than those who ate later. 
Implications: This is informational only.

title: A 3-minute brainwave test could spot Alzheimer’s years before symptoms
summary:
Summary: Researchers have developed a 3-minute brainwave test that can potentially detect Alzheimer's disease years before symptoms appear. The test analyzes brainwave patterns and shows promise in identifying early signs of the disease. 
Implications: This is informational only.

title: Metformin’s mysterious metal effect could explain its big health benefits
summary:
Summary: A new study suggests that metformin, a widely used diabetes drug, may exert its health benefits by influencing the way cells handle metals, particularly iron. This discovery could lead to the development of new drugs with similar effects. 
Implications: This is informational only.

title: Overworked neurons burn out and fuel Parkinson’s disease
summary:
Summary:  A new study suggests that overworked neurons in the brain can experience burnout, leading to the development of Parkinson's disease. This neuronal exhaustion is linked to the accumulation of toxic proteins, ultimately contributing to the death of dopamine-producing cells. 
Implications: This is informational only.

title: Hidden viruses in our DNA could be medicine’s next big breakthrough
summary:
Summary: Scientists have discovered that viruses embedded in our DNA, known as endogenous retroviruses (ERVs), may hold the key to developing new treatments for diseases like cancer and autoimmune disorders.  These ancient viral remnants could be harnessed to target specific cells or modulate the immune system. 

Implications: This is informational only.

title: Scientists discover how to wipe out breast cancer’s hidden cells
summary:
Summary: Scientists have identified a way to target and eliminate dormant breast cancer cells, which are resistant to traditional treatments and can lead to cancer recurrence. This discovery could lead to new therapies that prevent cancer from returning after initial treatment. 
Implications: This is informational only.

title: RFK Jr. pressed on vaccine accessibility. And, a plan for Ukraine's post-war safety
summary:
Summary: This NPR article discusses Robert F. Kennedy Jr.'s stance on vaccine accessibility and a plan for Ukraine's post-war safety.  It highlights Kennedy's criticism of vaccine mandates and his call for increased access to vaccines, particularly in underserved communities. 

Implications:  Doctors recommend vaccination. People should stay informed about vaccine availability and accessibility in their communities.

title: Health Secretary RFK Jr. grilled on vaccines and more during Senate hearing
summary:
Summary:  Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. faced intense questioning from senators during a hearing about his views on vaccines and other health issues. Kennedy Jr., a known vaccine skeptic, defended his stance while senators expressed concerns about his potential influence on public health policy. 
Implications: This is informational only.

title: 'One and done' dose of LSD keeps anxiety at bay
summary:
Summary: A new study suggests that a single dose of LSD can significantly reduce anxiety symptoms in people with generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) for up to a year. The effects were observed even after the drug's initial effects wore off. 
Implications: This is informational only.

title: States prepare alternative COVID vaccine plans to maintain access
summary:
Summary: As the federal government's COVID-19 vaccine contracts expire, states are developing backup plans to ensure continued vaccine access for their residents. These plans involve exploring partnerships with private companies and utilizing existing state resources to procure and distribute vaccines. 

Implications: This is informational only.

title: Experiencing pain? Sanjay Gupta explains why 'It Doesn't Have to Hurt'
summary:
Summary: Dr. Sanjay Gupta discusses the prevalence of chronic pain and emphasizes that it doesn't have to be a constant struggle. He highlights the importance of understanding pain, seeking help, and exploring various treatment options. 
Implications:  This is informational only.

title: Senators from both parties grilled RFK Jr. on vaccines and more
summary:
Summary: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. faced intense questioning from senators of both parties during a hearing on vaccines and his views on COVID-19.  The hearing focused on Kennedy's past statements and his role in promoting vaccine misinformation. 
Implications: This is informational only.

title: Why the medical community is thrilled by U.S. support for a 'breakthrough' HIV drug
summary:
Summary: The U.S. government has pledged significant funding to support the development and distribution of a new HIV prevention drug called lenacapavir, hailed as a "breakthrough" by medical professionals. Lenacapavir is a long-acting injectable that has shown promising results in clinical trials, potentially offering a more convenient and effective way to prevent HIV infection. 
Implications: This is informational only.

title: A clash of the comebacks: Anisimova outlasts Osaka in the U.S. Open semifinals
summary:
Summary: Amanda Anisimova defeated Naomi Osaka in a thrilling three-set match to advance to the U.S. Open final.  Anisimova's victory marks her first Grand Slam final appearance. 
Implications: This is informational only.

title: Over a billion people living with mental health conditions – services require urgent scale-up - World Health Organization (WHO)
summary:
Summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) reports that over a billion people globally are living with mental health conditions, emphasizing the urgent need to expand mental health services.  

Implications:  The WHO calls for increased investment and resources to scale up mental health services worldwide.

title: WHO Health Technology Access Programme - World Health Organization (WHO)
summary:
Summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has launched a new program called the Health Technology Access Programme (HTAP) to improve access to essential health technologies for low- and middle-income countries. The program aims to accelerate the development, deployment, and equitable distribution of these technologies. 
Implications: This is informational only.

title: WHO EPI-WIN Webinar: WHO infection prevention and control (IPC) and water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) in Health Emergency Readiness for Response Operations Capabilities Checklist - World Health Organization (WHO)
summary:
Summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) hosted a webinar on infection prevention and control (IPC) and water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) in health emergency readiness. The webinar focused on the WHO's IPC and WASH checklist for response operations capabilities. 
Implications: This is informational only.

title: WHO releases new reports and estimates highlighting urgent gaps in mental health - World Health Organization (WHO)
summary:
Summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has released new reports and estimates revealing significant gaps in mental health services globally. These reports highlight the urgent need for increased investment and action to address the growing mental health crisis. 
Implications: This is informational only.

title: 17th edition, Epidemiological Bulletin WHO Health Emergencies Programme WHO Regional Office for South-East Asia‎, 27 August 2025. Reporting period: 11 Aug to 24 Aug 2025 - World Health Organization (WHO)
summary:
Summary: The 17th edition of the WHO South-East Asia Regional Office's Epidemiological Bulletin reports on health emergencies and outbreaks in the region during the period of August 11th to 24th, 2025.  The bulletin covers various disease outbreaks, including dengue fever, chikungunya, and malaria, highlighting their geographical distribution and severity. 

Implications: This is informational only.

title: WHO EPI-WIN Webinar: community protection for cholera: Risk Communication and Community Engagement (RCCE) - World Health Organization (WHO)
summary:
Summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) hosted a webinar on community protection for cholera, focusing on risk communication and community engagement (RCCE) strategies.  The webinar aimed to provide guidance on effectively communicating cholera risks and engaging communities in prevention and response efforts. 
Implications: This is informational only.

title: WHO hosts first online training on the Urban Health Capacity Assessment and Response Resource Kit - World Health Organization (WHO)
summary:
Summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) recently hosted the first online training session on the Urban Health Capacity Assessment and Response Resource Kit. This resource kit aims to help cities strengthen their health systems and prepare for future health emergencies. 
Implications: This is informational only.

title: World Health Day 2025 - World Health Organization (WHO)
summary:
Summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has announced the theme for World Health Day 2025 as "Health for All," emphasizing the need for equitable access to healthcare and well-being for everyone.  The day aims to highlight the importance of universal health coverage and address health disparities. 
Implications: This is informational only.
